labour.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The garage charges £30 an hour for labour.
Many women do hard manual labour (=work with their hands).
Workers withdrew their labour (=protested by stopping work) for twenty-four hours.
labour.translation[0].definitions[1].def: all the people who work for a company or in a country
labour.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: We need to reduce our labour costs.
labour.translation[0].definitions[2].def: the process of giving birth to a baby
labour.translation[0].definitions[2].not: labour ward/room (=a room in a hospital where women give birth)
labour.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Diane went into labour at 2 o'clock.
Meg was in labour for ten hours.
labour.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 2: all the people who work for a company or in a country
labour.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Employers want to keep skilled labour because of the cost of training.
Women and children were used as cheap labour.
The industry makes use of a large supply of casual labour.
The shoe company was accused of using child labour in its factory.
Cotton was grown using slave labor.
We need an educated labour force.
What was the effect of the war on the labour supply?
the percentage of women in the labour market
Immigrants came into the country to fill the labour shortage.
There was pressure to keep down labour costs.
labour.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: They laboured all day in the mills.
I’ve been labouring over this report all morning.
Ray had little talent but labored to acquire the skills of a writer.
labour.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to move slowly and with difficulty
labour.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: I could see the bus labouring up the steep, windy road.
labour.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Most people will pay higher taxes under Labour.
labour.translation[3].definitions[0].def: work involving a lot of physical or mental effort
labour.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: The garage charges £65 an hour for labour.
those involved in repetitive, unskilled manual labour (=work that involves using your hands)
labour.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to stop working at your job for a period of time as a protest
labour.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Union members voted to withdraw their labour for 24 hours.
labour.translation[3].definitions[2].def: all the people who work for a company or in a country
labour.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: Some US companies relocate to Mexico in search of cheap labor (=people who are paid very low wages).
The airline’s labor costs are amongst the lowest in the industry.
